content.question: A student is riding a Ferris wheel that moves at a constant tangential speed around a vertical circular path of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure 1. The student is sitting on a scale. At the instant the moving student is located at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the scale exerts a force of magnitude <math alttext="F sub Scale" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mtext>Scale</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> on the student and Earth exerts a force of magnitude <math alttext="F sub Gravity" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> on the student, as shown in the free-body diagram in Figure 2. Which of the following statements provides reasoning that supports and correctly identifies the magnitude of the force that the student exerts on the scale when the student is at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub Scale" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mtext>Scale</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because that is the magnitude of the force exerted by the scale on the student.

<math alttext="F sub Scale" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mtext>Scale</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because that is the magnitude of the only upward force exerted on the student.

<math alttext="F sub Gravity" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because Earth exerts a gravitational force on the scale.

<math alttext="F sub Gravity" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the magnitude of the force exerted on a scale must equal the weight of the person on the scale.

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub Scale" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mtext>Scale</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because that is the magnitude of the force exerted by the scale on the student.
